newsitem.title: UK: Dlr firmer at Euro close, unfazed by benign CPI.
newsitem.headline: Dlr firmer at Euro close, unfazed by benign CPI.

text.p: The U.S. currency ended the European session firmer after benign U.S. inflation data did nothing to dissuade dollar bulls, traders said.
The dollar hit a fresh 29-month high against the mark at 1.5955 in the wake of consumer price figures showing a rise of just 0.1 percent in the core CPI rate.
Dollar/mark strength spilled over into dollar/yen, which ticked above 117 yen to a high of 117.04, also a fresh high.
The dollar took its cue from Treasuries buoyed by the benign inflation data. Economists expected a rise of 0.2 percent in the core rate. Retail sales rose 0.6 percent versus 0.5 expected.
"The data were mixed for the dollar but did nothing to substantially change the currency market's view about rising U.S. interest rates," said Robert Prior, European economist at HSBC James Capel.

"It's a market that bets on higher U.S. rates and lower German rates, and it wants to see the dollar go higher," said Prior. "And as long as you get data showing the economy is ticking along fine the dollar will extend its gains."
Benign inflation data tend to put a dampener on interest rate rise expectations while firm retail sales usually help to fuel them.
The subdued CPI data helped to dispel inflation fears sparked by robust non-farm payroll and average hourly earnings growth, as seen in the December jobs report last Friday.
Retail sales growth, meanwhile, looked robust enough to bet on strong fourth-quarter GDP data, analysts said.
"The data look consistent with fourth-quarter GDP of around the three percent mark, which is unsustainably strong for the Fed," said Jeremy Hawkins, senior economist at Bank of America.
"The bottom line is that growth is running close enough to inflation thresholds to keep the risk of Fed tightening very much alive," said Hawkins.

The dollar also gained on the back of comments from Bundesbank council member Helmut Hesse who said he could not rule out mark weakness in the run-up to European monetary union, as some investors may switch holdings into other currencies.

His colleague Olaf Sievert said earlier there was no reason why the German central bank should take a firmer grip on rates. Whether there was room for manoeuvre on the downside remained to be seen, he said.
Sievert also said the mark's 1995 appreciation had been corrected now, which put a slight dampener on the dollar in morning trade.

Chartists pointed to the dollar's still favourable technical outlook. The most immediate obstacle is a resistance line at around 1.5960 marks, dating back to the peaks of 1989. This would have to be broken convincincly to take on the 1.60 threshold.
The next target will be 1.6060, an area marking a 61.8 percent Fibonacci retracement of the entire decline from 1.7686 on February 28, 1994 to the record low at 1.3430 on March 31, 1995.
